name: Tomato - Two-spotted Spider Mite
description: A common and highly destructive plant pest, not an insect but an arachnid (mite). These tiny pests feed by piercing plant cells and sucking out their contents, causing a characteristic stippling on leaves, which can lead to severe plant stress, defoliation, and reduced yield.
symptoms: Tiny yellow or white speckles (stippling) on leaves
Fine silky webbing on leaf undersides and stems
Leaves turning yellow, bronze, or gray

early_stage.description: Light stippling on the upperside of leaves. Small colonies of mites and eggs visible on undersides (requires magnification).

middle_stage.description: Stippling becomes obvious. Leaves turn dull green or bronze. Fine webbing becomes visible, especially near leaf axils and growing tips.

advanced_stage.description: Heavy webbing covers the plant ('tents'). Leaves turn brown and crisp, then fall off. Plant vitality is severely compromised, potentially leading to death.

causes: Infestation by *Tetranychus urticae*. Mites disperse via wind, crawling between touching plants, or via humans/tools.

favorable_conditions.environment: **Hot, dry, and dusty conditions** are ideal for spider mite outbreaks. Low humidity, drought-stressed plants, and the overuse of broad-spectrum insecticides (which kill off their natural predators like ladybugs and predatory mites) strongly favor their rapid multiplication.

impact.economic_impact: Reduced yield, cosmetic damage to fruit (gold fleck), cost of control.

diagnosis.field_diagnosis: Shake leaves over white paper to see moving 'dust' specs. Check for webbing.
diagnosis.laboratory_diagnosis: Microscopic ID of adult mites (eight legs, two dark spots).

prevention: Maintain adequate plant hydration; spider mites thrive on stressed plants.
Regularly spray plants with water, focusing on the undersides of leaves, to increase humidity and dislodge mites.
Inspect new plants thoroughly before introducing them to your garden.

chemical_control: For mild infestations, a strong blast of water can be effective. Apply insecticidal soap or horticultural oil (like neem oil), ensuring **thorough coverage** of the entire plant, especially the undersides of leaves. Repeat applications every 5-7 days to control newly hatched mites. For severe cases, releasing predatory mites (*Phytoseiulus persimilis*) is an effective biological control, or specific chemical miticides can be used (rotate products to prevent resistance).

resistant_varieties: Some cultivars show tolerance (e.g., highly trichomed leaves)
life_cycle: Very rapid in heat. Egg to adult in as little as 5 days. Many generations per season.

dataset_metadata.intended_use: Machine learning training, research, and educational purpose
